frame.name: Performing_arts
frame.definition: <def-root>The <fen>Performer</fen>s, together with behind the scenes <fen>Personnel</fen>, execute a <fen>Performance</fen> according to a <fen>Script</fen> and/or <fen>Score</fen>. The purpose of the <fen>Performance</fen> is to create an experience for an <fen>Audience</fen>, who then judge its merits. <fen>Performance</fen>s may be in many different <fen>Medium</fen>s and be of various <fen>Type</fen>s. This frame is very elaborate in modern society and there are a number of traditions and practices typically (but not necessarily) related to <fen>Performance</fen>s: The <fen>Performance</fen> is preceded by many practice sessions in which the <fen>Performer</fen>s and other <fen>Personnel</fen> attempt to improve the quality and/or fidelity of their individual and collective performances to the Script and/or Score. The <fen>Audience</fen> members pay a fee to experience the <fen>Performance</fen>. The <fen>Performer</fen>s (and <fen>Personnel</fen>) receive payment for contributing to the <fen>Performance</fen>. Often there are other individuals involved in the specifically financial aspects of the <fen>Performance</fen> and <fen>Performer</fen>s. Critics act as part of the <fen>Audience</fen> and then write reviews that evaluate the merits of the <fen>Performance</fen>, describing the <fen>Performance</fen> to other potential <fen>Audience</fen> members. Due to the high quality of previous <fen>Performance</fen>s, <fen>Performer</fen>s can become famous, i.e. well known and liked. Those who like them particularly well become fans of the <fen>Performer</fen>. (Shared with writers...)</def-root>

FE.name: Personnel
FE.definition: <def-root>The <fen>Personnel</fen>, including writers, producers, stage hands, key grips, etc., contribute to the <fen>Performance</fen> without actually being directly perceived by the <fen>Audience</fen>.</def-root>

FE.name: Performance
FE.definition: <def-root>The experience generated by the <fen>Performer</fen>s and perceived by the <fen>Audience</fen>.</def-root>

FE.name: Script
FE.definition: <def-root>The (usually written) directions which instruct the <fen>Performer</fen>s on what actions to perform, when, and how. It has many different names depending on the <fen>Type</fen> of <fen>Performance</fen> including <ment>script</ment>, <ment>screenplay</ment>, <ment>libretto</ment>, <ment>book</ment>, and <ment>choreography</ment>.</def-root>

FE.name: Score
FE.definition: <def-root>The <fen>Score</fen> may be performed in the <fen>Performance</fen>, either in isolation or accompanying actions and speech.</def-root>

FE.name: Type
FE.definition: <def-root>This FE indicates the <fen>Type</fen> of <fen>Performance</fen>, including <ment>dance</ment>, <ment>theater</ment>, <ment>film</ment>, etc. </def-root>

FE.name: Medium
FE.definition: <def-root><fen>Medium</fen> is the physical entity or channel used by the <fen>Performer</fen> to transmit the <fen>Performance</fen> to the <fen>Audience</fen>.</def-root>

lexUnit.name: music.n
lexUnit.definition: COD: the art or science of combining vocal or instrumental sounds (or both) to produce beauty of form, harmony, and expression of emotion.

lexUnit.name: performance.n
lexUnit.definition: COD: an act of performing a play, concert, or other form of entertainment.

lexUnit.name: play.n
lexUnit.definition: COD: a dramatic work for the stage or to be broadcast.
